content: Several tax options have been proposed to finance health care reform, including restricting itemized deductions for high-income taxpayers, modifying the tax exclusion for employer-provided health care, increasing taxes on alcoholic beverages, and imposing an excise tax on non-diet sweetened beverages. The House Ways and Means Committee proposed a surtax on high-income individuals, while the Senate Finance Committee reported a bill relying on an excise tax on insurers for high-cost plans. The House and Senate proposed various tax options to finance health care reform, including a surtax on high-income individuals and an excise tax on insurers for high-cost plans. President Obama's compromise proposal, based on H.R. 3590, included delaying the tax on high-cost employer plans to 2018 and raising the exemption threshold. The House passed H.R. 3590 and H.R. 4872, which were signed into law in March 2010. The tax proposals to finance health care reform included a 3.8% tax on unearned income. The House passed H.R. 3590 and H.R. 4872, signed into law in March 2010. The tax proposals varied in their impact on income distribution, with some affecting higher-income taxpayers more heavily. The tax proposals for health care reform include increases for high-income taxpayers, particularly affecting the top 1-2%. Limiting health-related income and payroll-tax exclusions increases taxes more for middle-income brackets. Excise taxes are regressive, impacting lower-income classes more. Despite regressive revenue sources, the overall proposal may benefit lower-income individuals. Various revenue raisers have been proposed by the House, Senate, and President Obama, along with other financing proposals. The revenue raisers proposed in the House, Senate, and by President Obama for health care reform include increased Medicare tax, fees on health insurance providers, "Cadillac" tax on employer health insurance premiums, and fees on branded drugs. These provisions account for about 90% of revenues over FY2010-FY2019, with the Medicare tax alone contributing 48%. Other provisions include the cellulosic biofuel credit, fees on medical devices, and tax compliance provision for reporting payments over $600. The shares of revenue sources change over time due to delays and expirations.
